posts.name: Mark
posts.cooked:
I am trying to communicate a set of values from my C++  code running on the rPi using network tables. But I cannot figure out how to convert my std::vector into an nt::ArrayRef in order to be able to pass it back.

Can someone please guide me.

Here is my code â€¦

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
I do not know Cpp that well, but would an array of vectors actually be a 2d array? If that is the case, I could see why this could fail.

I wonder if you casted the vectors as strings and then casted them back to vectors on the robot (and/or driver station) if that would work.

Mind you, I know little about the two libraries in question so I could be totally wrong.

Also, there could be a better way to accomplish this.

posts.name: KJaget
posts.cooked: We have code which just passes the vector itself into SetDoubleArray.  It compiles, I havenâ€™t tested it in a while but give it a try on in your code.

link_counts.title: WPILibC++: wpi::ArrayRef< T > Class Template Reference

posts.name: Mark
posts.cooked: Thank You @KJaget for your response, Can you please point me to the example code, I am not seeing anything to be able to try.

posts.name: Mark
posts.cooked:
Hello @Mr.R_2 , A 1D array can be a vector, think of a 1D-Look-up table that is of length 20 (in my example).  The code that generates the array as a std::vector is fine, I am having a hard time knowing how to convert it to an ArrayRef.

I have reviewed the documentation that @Joe_Ross suggested many times, but cannot figure out how to make it work.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
ArrayRef has an implicit conversion from vector, so you can just pass your vector directly, no need to explicitly convert it.

Note: in 2022 ArrayRef is replaced by span (a backport of C++20â€™s std::span ), but the concept is the same: a std::vector will implicitly convert to a span.

posts.cooked:

e have code which just passes the vector itself into SetDoubleArray. It compiles, I havenâ€™t tested it in a while but give it a try on in your code.

I dont know what I am missing.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Those are notes, not errors.  Does the build still succeed?

posts.name: Mark
posts.cooked: My bad, yes, the build did complete. Thank you for enlightening me on that subtle but important difference I will test it and post back to let people know if they show up in the Network table server.

posts.name: Mark
posts.cooked:
Hi All,

Thank you for your responses, I have tested this using the simulator and can see that the table is being created and updated in the network server as the code is running.

Thank you for everyoneâ€™s help.

Just a note for those that may be reading this in the futureâ€¦

Visual Studio Code and IntelliJ were both telling me that the two data types were not compatible which started me down this path. So, the lesson learned was to try compiling it, and then go from there.  I wasted many hours trying to figure out why the IDE was showing an error in my code â€¦ that would have been saved.

Mark

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Something that will hopefully help in the future: as I mentioned earlier, one of the improvements weâ€™re making in C++ for WPILib 2022 is moving more towards C++ standard library components (or at least standards-track components) for interfaces, particularly as C++17 and C++20 add similar classes to the (very useful) LLVM classes weâ€™ve used to date:

wpi::StringRef is being replaced by std::string_view .  This is a drop-in replacement for most use cases; std::string_view doesnâ€™t have all the convenience functions that StringRef did, so weâ€™ve added these as free functions to wpi/StringExtras.h.

wpi::ArrayRef is being replaced by wpi::span, which is an exact drop-in for C++20 std::span .  We unfortunately canâ€™t use the C++20 one yet due to lacking compiler support, but this will ease a future transition.  Similar to the case for StringRef, span doesnâ€™t have the same convenience functions as ArrayRef, so weâ€™ve added these as free functions to wpi/SpanExtras.h.

wpi::Twine is being replaced by fmtlib .  Twine had some nice features and is more efficient in a handful of use cases, but fmtlib is a lot easier to understand, has better docs, will be largely standardized in C++20 as std::format , and has fewer potential trip points for users.

We realize this will cause some short-term pain for teams upgrading, but expect it to pay off over the long term due to better docs / online resources from using standard library components.
